content.question: At the moment shown, an electron is moving parallel to a current carrying wire with an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in the same direction as the current. Which of the following correctly describes the change, if any, to the magnitude of the electronâ€™s acceleration <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>a</mi></mstyle></math> as it moves in the region, and provides a correct justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> decreases because the electron moves parallel to the magnetic field created by the current in the wire, resulting in work done on the electron by the magnetic field.

<math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> decreases because the electron is deflected away from the wire, resulting in a smaller force exerted on the electron by the magnetic field created by the current in the wire.

<math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> does not change because the magnetic field created by the current in the wire can only change the direction of the velocity of a moving charged particle, but not its magnitude.

<math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> does not change because the electric force exerted on the electron by charged particles in the wire balances the force exerted on the electron by the magnetic field created by the current in the wire.

content.answer: <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> decreases because the electron is deflected away from the wire, resulting in a smaller force exerted on the electron by the magnetic field created by the current in the wire.
